files.patch:
@@ -56,1 +56,1 @@
-JMC_RCP_P2_UPDATESITE_NICK_NAME=JDK Mission Control 8.0.0 RCP Update Site
\ No newline at end of file
+JMC_RCP_P2_UPDATESITE_NICK_NAME=JDK Mission Control 8.1.0 RCP Update Site
\ No newline at end of file

@@ -36,1 +36,1 @@
-# "{0}" will be replaced by the version number of JDK Mission Control, e.g. "8.0.0"
+# "{0}" will be replaced by the version number of JDK Mission Control, e.g. "8.1.0"

@@ -52,1 +52,1 @@ -

Version 8.0.0 is now available. It supports the HotSpot VM (Oracle JDK 8 and up, OpenJDK 11). +

Version 8.1.0 is now available. It supports the HotSpot VM (Oracle JDK 8 and up, OpenJDK 11). @@ -55,1 +55,1 @@ -

Note that any prior versions of JMC MUST BE UNINSTALLED from Eclipse before installing JMC 8.0.0.

+

Note that any prior versions of JMC MUST BE UNINSTALLED from Eclipse before installing JMC 8.1.0.

@@ -76,1 +76,1 @@ -
  • Requires Eclipse 4.16 or later.
    • +
  • Requires Eclipse 4.19 or later.
    • @@ -78,2 +78,2 @@ -
  • Note that you need to run your Eclipse on a JDK (version 8 or above) installation for all features to work. For more information on this, - especially for JDK 9, please see the Run Eclipse on JDK HOWTO.
    • +
  • Note that you need to run your Eclipse on a JDK (version 11 or above) installation for all features to work. For more information on this, + please see the Run Eclipse on JDK HOWTO.
    • @@ -95,1 +95,1 @@ - Version 8.0.0 is now available. It supports the HotSpot VM and JDK Flight Recorder.

    + Version 8.1.0 is now available. It supports the HotSpot VM and JDK Flight Recorder.

    @@ -113,1 +113,1 @@ - JDK Mission Control is a set of plug-ins for Eclipse 4.16 or later.

    + JDK Mission Control is a set of plug-ins for Eclipse 4.19 or later.

@@ -37,3 +37,3 @@ -

The easiest way to change the JVM on which to start Eclipse is by modifying the eclipse.ini file. You can also set the -vm on the command line used to start Eclipse. In windows you would typically do that in the shortcut you use to launch Eclipse. Here is an example ini file:

-showsplash
org.eclipse.platform
-vm
D:/java/jdk1.8.0_261/bin/

-

You can also configure JVM options by using -vmargs on commandline or eclipse.ini:

-showsplash
org.eclipse.platform
-vm
D:/java/jdk1.8.0_261/bin/
-vmargs
<JVM options on separate lines>

-

If you use JDK 11 (or later) to run Eclipse, the following JVM options are needed for JDK Mission Control to work properly:

+

The easiest way to change the JVM on which to start Eclipse is by modifying the eclipse.ini file. You can also set the -vm on the command line used to start Eclipse. In windows you would typically do that in the shortcut you use to launch Eclipse. Here is an example ini file:

-showsplash
org.eclipse.platform
-vm
D:/java/jdk-11.0.11/bin/

+

You can also configure JVM options by using -vmargs on commandline or eclipse.ini:

-showsplash
org.eclipse.platform
-vm
D:/java/jdk-11.0.11/bin/
-vmargs
<JVM options on separate lines>

+

The following JVM options are needed for JDK Mission Control to work properly:

@@ -46,1 +46,1 @@ - Before starting, make sure that you have downloaded and installed Eclipse 4.16 or later. + Before starting, make sure that you have downloaded and installed Eclipse 4.19 or later. @@ -79,1 +79,1 @@ -

https://download.oracle.com/technology/products/missioncontrol/updatesites/openjdk/8.0.0/eclipse/

+

https://download.oracle.com/technology/products/missioncontrol/updatesites/openjdk/8.1.0/eclipse/
